slides.title: The Problem üìà
slides.content:
# Too Big

Traditional SQL databases scale **Vertically** (Bigger CPU, More RAM).

NoSQL databases are designed to scale **Horizontally** (Add more cheap servers).

Scaling is built-in, not an afterthought.

slides.title: Sharding
slides.content:
# Partitioning üç∞

Distributing data across multiple servers (Shards).

**Shard Key:** Determines which server holds a piece of data.
`User ID 1-1000` -> Server A
`User ID 1001-2000` -> Server B

slides.title: Replication
slides.content:
# copying üëØ

Keep multiple copies of data on different servers.

- **Primary (Master):** Accepts writes.
- **Secondary (Replica):** Accepts reads (and takes over if Primary dies).

Increases Read Scalability and Availability.

slides.title: Replica Sets
slides.content:
# MongoDB Example

A cluster of N nodes.

1 Primary, N-1 Secondaries.

Automatic failover: If Primary crashes, Secondaries vote and elect a new Primary in seconds.

slides.title: Consistent Hashing
slides.content:
# The Ring üíç

Used in Cassandra/DynamoDB.

Servers are arranged in a ring.

Data is hashed to a position on the ring.

Adding/Removing a server only affects its immediate neighbors, minimizing data movement.

slides.title: Direction Quiz
quizOptions: Buying a bigger, more expensive server
Adding more servers to the cluster

slides.title: CAP Theorem
slides.content:
# Trade-offs ‚öñÔ∏è

Choose 2:
- **Consistency:** Everyone sees same data roughly same time.
- **Availability:** Always get a response.
- **Partition Tolerance:** Works even if network cuts.

NoSQL usually picks AP or CP.

slides.title: Eventual Consistency
slides.content:
# BASE Model

**Basically Available, Soft state, Eventual consistency.**

Standard for AP systems (Cassandra).

"I wrote data to Node A. You might read from Node B and see old data for a few milliseconds, but eventually it will sync."

slides.title: Read vs Write Scaling
slides.content:
# Strategies

- **Read Heavy:** Add more replicas (Secondaries/Slaves).
- **Write Heavy:** Add more Shards (Masters).

slides.title: Geo-Replication
slides.content:
# Global Speed üåç

Replicate data to data centers across the world.

Users read from the data center closest to them (Low Latency).

Also serves as Disaster Recovery.

slides.title: Hotspots
slides.content:
# Bad Key ü•µ

If you choose a bad Shard Key (e.g., "Celebrity User ID"), all traffic goes to ONE server.

Good Shard Key spreads traffic evenly (High cardinality, high randomness).

slides.title: Consistency Quiz
quizOptions: Data is always immediately consistent everywhere
Data might be stale for a moment, but will sync up over time
Only the admin sees the consistent data

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Scaling üì∂

Handling Billions.

- **Sharding:** Writes.
- **Replication:** Reads.
- **CAP:** Trade-offs.
- **Partition:** Horizontal.
